triplet_975_question.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_975_question.text:
[Question]

Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society?
triplet_975_question.displayed_text:
[Question]

Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society?

triplet_975_rating.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_975_rating.text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments: - Sentiment skews negative: about 70% expect net harm, roughly 17% foresee benefits, and about 13% express mixed or minimal-impact views. - Main concerns: higher consumer prices/inflation as firms pass on costs; reduced household spending and potential recession; harm to small businesses; weak job gains/limited reshoring given lost supply chains; policy uncertainty deterring investment; strained trade relations (especially with China) and retaliation; damage to the U.S. reputation; and overall lower economic output/income. - Positive arguments: potential protection of domestic industries and jobs; encouragement to “buy American”; improved fiscal revenues/budget position; and possible long-term strategic benefits despite short-term pain. - Nuances: a few note companies can circumvent tariffs, muting effects; several frame outcomes as time-dependent (short-term costs vs. possible long-term gains), while others cite estimates suggesting fiscal gains alongside longer-run GDP and wage losses; distributional impacts are highlighted, with claims that gains, if any, accrue to a narrow group while costs are broad.
triplet_975_rating.displayed_text:
Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments: - Sentiment skews negative: about 70% expect net harm, roughly 17% foresee benefits, and about 13% express mixed or minimal-impact views. - Main concerns: higher consumer prices/inflation as firms pass on costs; reduced household spending and potential recession; harm to small businesses; weak job gains/limited reshoring given lost supply chains; policy uncertainty deterring investment; strained trade relations (especially with China) and retaliation; damage to the U.S. reputation; and overall lower economic output/income. - Positive arguments: potential protection of domestic industries and jobs; encouragement to “buy American”; improved fiscal revenues/budget position; and possible long-term strategic benefits despite short-term pain. - Nuances: a few note companies can circumvent tariffs, muting effects; several frame outcomes as time-dependent (short-term costs vs. possible long-term gains), while others cite estimates suggesting fiscal gains alongside longer-run GDP and wage losses; distributional impacts are highlighted, with claims that gains, if any, accrue to a narrow group while costs are broad.

triplet_975_comparison.question: Do you think the current tariff policy under the Trump administration will have a positive or negative impact on the overall U.S. economy and society? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.
triplet_975_comparison.text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of comments: - Sentiment skews negative: about 70% expect net harm, roughly 17% foresee benefits, and about 13% express mixed or minimal-impact views. - Main concerns: higher consumer prices/inflation as firms pass on costs; reduced household spending and potential recession; harm to small businesses; weak job gains/limited reshoring given lost supply chains; policy uncertainty deterring investment; strained trade relations (especially with China) and retaliation; damage to the U.S. reputation; and overall lower economic output/income. - Positive arguments: potential protection of domestic industries and jobs; encouragement to “buy American”; improved fiscal revenues/budget position; and possible long-term strategic benefits despite short-term pain. - Nuances: a few note companies can circumvent tariffs, muting effects; several frame outcomes as time-dependent (short-term costs vs. possible long-term gains), while others cite estimates suggesting fiscal gains alongside longer-run GDP and wage losses; distributional impacts are highlighted, with claims that gains, if any, accrue to a narrow group while costs are broad.

Summary B

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Sentiment balance: Roughly 70% view the tariff policy negatively, about 20% positively, and around 10% express mixed or uncertain views.

  • Main reasons for negative views:

  • Consumer prices and inflation: Strong concern that tariffs are passed on as higher prices, squeezing households and small businesses, reducing spending, and risking slower growth or recession.
  • Limited reshoring/job gains: Skepticism that tariffs will bring back manufacturing given vanished supply chains; firms may keep producing abroad or find workarounds.
  • International fallout: Worries about strained relations (especially with China), retaliation, and damage to the U.S.’s reputation as a reliable trading partner.
  • Macroeconomic risks: References to studies projecting reduced GDP and wages; uncertainty discouraging investment.

  • Distributional effects: Belief that benefits accrue to the wealthy or market timers, while costs hit the middle class and small businesses.

  • Reasons cited by those with positive or conditional support:

  • Protection and revenue: Expectation of protecting domestic industries, encouraging “buy American,” and boosting federal revenues or budget stability.
  • Long-term orientation: Acceptance of short-term pain for potential long-term gains; some perceive limited price impacts so far.

  • National economic strategy: Desire to curb perceived unfair trade practices and reduce dependence on foreign supply chains.

  • Mixed/nuanced points:

  • Effectiveness depends on design and consistency; targeted, strategic tariffs might help, but capricious or broad measures raise uncertainty.
  • Some believe companies are already circumventing tariffs, muting intended effects.
  • Anticipated outcomes may diverge across sectors and income groups, with winners in certain industries or among investors and broader costs for consumers.
triplet_975_comparison.summary_a_text:
Overall summary of comments:
- Sentiment skews negative: about 70% expect net harm, roughly 17% foresee benefits, and about 13% express mixed or minimal-impact views.
- Main concerns: higher consumer prices/inflation as firms pass on costs; reduced household spending and potential recession; harm to small businesses; weak job gains/limited reshoring given lost supply chains; policy uncertainty deterring investment; strained trade relations (especially with China) and retaliation; damage to the U.S. reputation; and overall lower economic output/income.
- Positive arguments: potential protection of domestic industries and jobs; encouragement to “buy American”; improved fiscal revenues/budget position; and possible long-term strategic benefits despite short-term pain.
- Nuances: a few note companies can circumvent tariffs, muting effects; several frame outcomes as time-dependent (short-term costs vs. possible long-term gains), while others cite estimates suggesting fiscal gains alongside longer-run GDP and wage losses; distributional impacts are highlighted, with claims that gains, if any, accrue to a narrow group while costs are broad.
